remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you’ve been experiencing shortness of breath and swelling in both legs—can you tell me more about when these symptoms first began and how they have changed over time?

remedi_labels.value: how they have changed over time

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… yes, I’ve been having a lot more shortness of breath lately. It feels like it’s getting harder to breathe, especially when I’m moving around. I guess that’s what you’d call increased work of breathing? That’s really what’s worrying me the most right now.

Thank you for sharing that—it’s important that we understand how your symptoms are affecting your daily activities. In addition to the increased shortness of breath with exertion, have you noticed any difficulty breathing when lying flat or waking up at night short of breath, which we call orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea?

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for sharing that—it’s important that we understand how your symptoms are affecting your daily activities.
waking up at night short of breath
which we call orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… I have noticed the shortness of breath is worse when I’m lying down. Sometimes at night I wake up kind of gasping, I think that’s what you called paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea? It’s been happening more lately, and it makes me pretty anxious, to be honest.

remedi_labels.value: shortness of breath worse when lying down

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about waking up short of breath—that must be very unsettling. You also mentioned swelling in both legs; can you describe how severe the swelling has become and whether it has changed recently?

Um, yes, the swelling in my legs has definitely gotten worse. It used to just be a little puffiness around my ankles, but now it goes up to my calves. I think you’d call that lower extremity edema? It’s not super painful, but it feels tight and uncomfortable, especially by the end of the day. I’m a bit anxious about it, since it seems to be getting worse along with the dyspnea. Should I be worried about these symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: tight and uncomfortable feeling in legs
Should I be worried about these symptoms?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—worsening swelling and difficulty breathing at night can be very concerning. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any sudden weight gain or a rapid increase in the amount of swelling in your legs over the past few days?

remedi_labels.value: rapid increase in swelling in legs

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Let me think… I haven’t really been examinationing my weight every day, but my pants and socks feel tighter than usual, so maybe I have gained some fluid? The swelling in my legs definitely seemed to get worse pretty quickly over the last few days. I’m not sure exactly how much, but it feels like the edema is more noticeable now.

Thank you for describing how the swelling and shortness of breath have progressed. To further assess your symptoms, have you noticed any changes in your urine output or any abdominal discomfort that might suggest fluid accumulation elsewhere in your clinical examination?

Well, um… I haven’t really noticed much change in my urine output, I think it’s about the same. But now that you mention it, I did have an episode of nausea and some dry heaving the other night. It happened after I woke up with that paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea—waking up gasping for air. I didn’t actually vomit much, but it was pretty uncomfortable and made me more anxious. I don’t think I’ve had any real abdominal pain, though.

I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with the worsening swelling and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any chest discomfort, palpitations, or irregular heartbeats associated with your shortness of breath or during these nighttime episodes?

remedi_labels.value: shortness of breath during nighttime episodes

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Actually, yes—I have noticed that my heart sometimes feels like it’s beating funny, kind of jumpy and out of rhythm. I think that’s what you’d call an irregularly irregular rhythm? It happens off and on, and sometimes I get a little fluttering feeling in my chest. I haven’t really had much chest discomfort, but the palpitations make me more anxious, especially when I’m already short of breath.

Um, I remember one of my previous doctors mentioned something about a holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border—does that have anything to do with these symptoms? I just worry because everything seems to be happening at once. Should I be concerned about my heart with all of this going on?

remedi_labels.value: holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border
Does holosystolic murmur relate to current symptoms?
Should I be concerned about my heart with these symptoms?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious, especially with the combination of swelling in your legs, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and palpitations. To further clarify your symptoms, have you noticed any changes in your breathing or swelling after taking your diuretic (Lasix), or do these symptoms persist despite your current medication regimen?

Well, um… I’ve been taking my Lasix just like I’m supposed to, but honestly, the shortness of breath and swelling haven’t really improved much. Maybe the swelling in my calves goes down a tiny bit in the morning, but by the evening it’s back to being pretty noticeable—like 1+ pitting edema, I think you’d call it? And the dyspnea is still there, even when I try to rest.

When I was in the hospital before, someone mentioned I had minimal bibasilar crackles on my exam—does that mean there’s fluid in my lungs again? I’m just worried that even with all these medications, my symptoms aren’t getting better. Should I be doing something differently, or is this a sign that my heart or lungs are getting worse?

remedi_labels.value: does minimal bibasilar crackles mean there’s fluid in my lungs again
should I be doing something differently
is this a sign that my heart or lungs are getting worse

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially since your symptoms of lower extremity edema and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea have not improved despite taking your medications as prescribed. Well, um… I haven’t really had much of a cough lately—maybe just a little bit here and there, but nothing like when I had that multifocal pneumonia a while back. I don’t have any wheezing or extra sputum, either. It’s mostly just this persistent shortness of breath, especially when I try to do anything around the house—like even walking to the kitchen makes me feel winded. I guess you’d call that dyspnea on exertion?

And the lower extremity edema is still there, like I mentioned, and it just seems to be sticking around no matter what I do. I’m honestly pretty anxious about all of this. Is it normal for these symptoms to keep coming back, even with all my medications? Should I be worried that something more serious is going on with my heart or lungs?

remedi_labels.value: persistent shortness of breath (dyspnea on exertion)

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious, especially since your symptoms of persistent lower extremity edema and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea have not improved despite your current medications. Based on your medical history and recent examination findings—including swelling in both legs, difficulty breathing at night, and minimal bibasilar crackles—these symptoms suggest ongoing fluid overload, likely related to your underlying cardiac condition. To further guide my assessment, have you noticed any recent changes in your appetite or episodes of confusion, which can sometimes be associated with worsening heart failure or electrolyte imbalances?

remedi_labels.value: ongoing fluid overload likely related to underlying cardiac condition

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
